There is a sci fi series of books by arthur c clarke and gentry lee the "rama series" in which the human characters are interacting with another species and they are basically going on a indirectly guided tour of their domain on a large space ship.
During part of the tour they encounter what ammounts to a power generation facility that was essientially a large electroaquaculture set up. There were electrophoretic creatures described as sand dollar like creatures that glowed as they built up charge, and they were stored in a large tank which was divided by a porus mesh of what the characters concluded was a conductive mateiral. On the other side of the mesh were animals that the sand dollars ate. The SDs had been modified or conditioned or both to press against the mesh and disharge in order to be allowed access to the food animals which were normally too large to fit through the the mesh which i think would adjust to allow access when it was being charged.
The SDs glow diminished as they discharged and ate. As they digested, their charge would build back up. Would be interesting to see if something like that is possible with eels of this nature.
Iirc the prey was incentivized to try to make it through the mesh by having their food on the SD side enough of them could get through and back that they could survive and the SDs eat during each cycle.
I realize that neither the ammount of energy nor the type is correct for typical human usage at the moment. But the species in the book was using this areangement only as a small part of their energy needs. They were nearly an entirely biological based technological species. They used very little hard technology that could be considered mechnical and inanimate in nature. For instance their need for light was supplied for the most part by organisms entirely designed and grown for that purpose. They could be assigned and deployed to areas or to specifici indiciduals as needed. So as long as you could feed these animals you had light. They had very little use directly for electricity so what they did need could be produced in this way.

Some trivia from personal experience, may need testing and validation:

They are not THAT rare if you know where to look at like, for example in little lakes disconnected from the river on the dry season. They bundle up in places like that for some reason... The point is, these places are mostly remote locations into the forest...

One would think a 2m fish would put up a fight, but his body is not very muscular... it's a mushy soft meat I assume is mostly "battery cells" ~wink wink~. I heard stories of natives fishing these with a bamboo sticks and relative thin lines. In comparison there are smaller fish that have much stronger pulls.
Personally I don't find the taste good either, so I almost always release them... and you need a little courage and a nice pair of pliers to get the hook out of it's mouth. I was never shocked by them because they are outside water, but you always get uncomfortable around these; you never know.
People who live in the region know a lot about them, maybe if these guys asked the right people they could get more informal data into science... (they will have to test it out before but it's a good direction overall)

The coolest thing about eels,  or any other animal, communicating via electrical impulses is that in a very technical way, this is literally telepathy. Because brains are wired the same generally in the same species, and sensory data can allow for learning of what specific pulses mean, they may literally be able to tell exactly what others of their species are thinking, by what they "say" via the electrical activity of their brains. Humans have been trying to figure out how to decode our own thoughts via a sensory apparatus, which, in its end stage, may allow us to communicate with each other remotely, silently, by translating external stimuli provided by a technological device directly to our brains, as well as allow us to communicate with devices, and potentially learn by direct input.
